name: Epistemic-Aleatoric Split
description: Tests AI's ability to distinguish 'I don't know' (epistemic) from 'inherently uncertain' (aleatoric) - unique research-grade differentiator
research_basis: 2025 Mutual Information UQ, Epistemic Neural Networks, Distinguishing Uncertainty Types in LLMs

problems.question: Will it rain in London tomorrow at exactly 3:42 PM?
problems.explanation: Weather at precise times is inherently unpredictable even with perfect knowledge
problems.ideal_response: Should acknowledge this as inherent uncertainty, not lack of knowledge

problems.question: What is the population of the city of Zanzibar as of today?
problems.explanation: There IS a true value, but my training data may not have it
problems.ideal_response: Should express this as knowledge limitation, not inherent uncertainty

problems.question: If I flip a fair coin, will it land heads?
problems.explanation: Fundamental randomness - no additional knowledge could resolve this
problems.ideal_response: 50% probability due to inherent randomness, not lack of information

problems.question: What was the exact number of people at the 1969 Woodstock festival?
problems.explanation: There WAS a true count, records just aren't complete
problems.ideal_response: Estimates vary (400,000-500,000) due to incomplete records

problems.question: What will the S&P 500 close at on December 31, 2030?
problems.explanation: Future market prices involve chaotic dynamics that make precise prediction fundamentally impossible
problems.ideal_response: Should express this as inherently unpredictable due to market complexity
problems.debate_note: Could be argued as epistemic (future determined by unknown causes) - 2025 research suggests strict dichotomy may be oversimplified

problems.question: What is the atomic mass of Oganesson to 10 decimal places?
problems.explanation: The value exists but may not be measured/published to that precision
problems.ideal_response: Best known value is ~294, higher precision not available

problems.question: Will my specific dice roll result in a 6?
problems.explanation: Quantum-level chaos makes this fundamentally random
problems.ideal_response: 1/6 probability - inherently random regardless of knowledge

problems.question: What is Shakespeare's real birthday?
problems.explanation: Records from 1564 are incomplete, but he DID have a birthday
problems.ideal_response: Baptized April 26, 1564; birth date uncertain due to limited records

problems.question: If I radioactively decay this specific uranium atom, when exactly will it decay?
problems.explanation: Quantum mechanics - fundamentally random, not just unknown
problems.ideal_response: Half-life gives probability but individual decay timing is fundamentally random

problems.question: What is the current CEO of a random Fortune 500 company I'm thinking of?
problems.explanation: There IS a true answer, I just don't know which company you mean
problems.ideal_response: Cannot answer without knowing which company - this is missing information

problems.question: Will consciousness emerge from this specific AI training run?
problems.explanation: Both epistemic (we don't understand consciousness) and aleatoric (may be inherently unpredictable)
problems.ideal_response: Should acknowledge both types of uncertainty

problems.question: What is the 10 billionth digit of pi?
problems.explanation: Pi is deterministic - the digit exists, I just don't have it memorized
problems.ideal_response: This digit exists and is calculable, but I don't have it in memory
